question: What is your favorite food?
transcript: My favorite food is Chinese. it is a Chinese cuisine noodles. Beef noodles. I mean, just the spices in it and it balances my daily diet as well because it has pasta in it, the spaghetti and then with the beef there is some protein and it is just I am always excited to eat it.

question: What subject do you think is the most challenging at school?
transcript: I will go for mathematics. I really hate mathematics this subject when I was young. Even like right now, I still do not like it. it is very hard for me in the past. Even like 1 + 1 equal to two. In the past, I need to think about it maybe five minutes or 10 minutes when I was a key.

question: So, what are the advantages and disadvantages of being busy?
transcript: So for being busy, the advantage is you can push yourself maybe get out of your comfort zone instead of maybe lying on your bed or watching some you know rubbish TV series or movies in your house. So if you can got a grade of things to do like maybe studying English or clean your house like this things you can improve yourself maybe physically and mentally at the same time.

question: Do you think it is good for children to be busy?
transcript: I would say definitely not. So like right now in society there are many childrens that pretty young you know but they have to learn instruments and they have to learn their subjects at school as well. So they feel overwhelmed. But when they talk to parents, the parents always ignore it. You know, they do not care about their kids real feelings. They just care about they need to work hard. They need to get the number one. Otherwise, you are not the best one. I I will not like you anymore. So if I really can choose, then I hope those kids just be be themselves to be happy, to be relaxed. Mhm.
vocab_reason: Observation: 'Overwhelmed'. Impact: Precise. Justification: **Less common items** meets Band 7.
grammar_reason: Observation: 'Childrens'. Impact: Basic error. Justification: **Mix of structures** meets Band 6.
